summary: slf4jbridgehandler causes infinite logging loop and stackoverflowerror on glassfish
description: deploying nexus on glassfish fails with a stackoverflowerror in the admin console
this exception is not logged so i had to attach a debugger to find out what happened
i found out that glassfish overrides system.out to with a custom printwriter that redirects to the java logging system
they probably thought this was a smart trick to catch the output of any code that writes to system.out instead of using proper logging

the problem is that nexus uses slf4jbridgehandler to redirect all jul logging to again wraps nexus configures with a consoleappender writing to system.out so what happens is this some code writes to a plexus logger component

the plexus logger component logs to logger in form plexus logging logs to writes result to system.out through the configured consoleappender custom system.out redirect console output to java logging redirects logging to becuse of slf4jbridgehandler being installed
see so we have an infinite loop in logging ending in a stackoverflowerror
confirmed that removing slf4jhandlerinstaller from plexus.xml prevents the loop and that nexus actually starts up on glassfish when this change is made
i guess the slf4jhandlerinstaller is probably there for a reason so just removing it is probably not the best way to fix this
btw the nexus faq states that glassfish is not yet supported as it conflicts with this should probably be updated because really the problem here

the actual write docacheitem call was protected well but the pool was already exhausted and nexus was

summary: optimize memory usage by ehcache in nexus
description: right now the ehcache.xml accessible and meant to be modified by users defines the following defaults showing the most interesting part since nexus keeps one ehcache instance per repository currently the user should be aware that nexus instances with large number of repositories defined may deplete memory available to jvm
example is our where reposes are defined
according to jhat one entry in ehcache consumes bytes

so a simple math the potential maximum is numberofreposes maxelementsinmemory instance of instances circa mb so memory of around is the theoretical maximum when ehcache will start apply the defined lfu policy to make more space in filled cache instance
until cache is not full ehcache does nothing to remove expired elements from cache and thus from memory
another problem is shown here say you have a normal nexus instance normal by the number of defined also say you have a public group that holds all defined reposes as members
if you request by mistake artifact foo from your public group the same foo will get into nfc of all defined reposes
up to this it is okay
but the nfc entry of artifact foo will be kept in memory forever all the time that nexus instance is up since nothing removes it

right now eviction is done only on incoming requests and if foo was request by mistake for example this instance was not meant at all to be asked for foo it will just sit in memory as long as instance lives
we have to fix this

summary: artifact upload and logging page do not work if cookies are disabled
description: we should either not allow the user to login if a cookie is not set or we should warn and hide of things that will not work if cookies are disabled or not accepted thread from the mail list richard i just tried to upload a jar file to the thirdparty repository using the upload functionality in the ui
brian this is a known problem
ext wraps the file upload in an iframe and the response codes vaporize with when the frame is done

chances are this is a permission problem where the user didn't have the ability to write to that repo richard ok so i figured i could just copy the file from my local repo to the place where nexus expects it
did that and it worked
the repo browser showed the file the maven build found it
brian this will work but caches and indexes aren't updated
you need to expire the caches and force an index before everything will be updated
richard next i tried that with a few other files copied them they showed up in the repo browser but a download right click in the repo browser or direct link access in the browser failed
i got some random status page about an error
again the log is silent
rebuilding meta data did not help
brian i'm guessing that it was in the negative cache and changes to the disk directly don't flush that cache you would need to do it manually
richard after that i tried deploying from the command line which finally worked
brian yep this would have updated all the caches correctly
richard i just figured that the upload problems were due to disabled cookies
also downloading the log file results in an empty page if cookies are disabled
after enabling cookies the problems were gone
i use a firefox plugin that disables cookie by default and only allow them by site if necessary
so i'd suggest you should either require cookies and not let the user log in without or make sure everything works without cookies

summary: clean up or fix the identity problem in nexus core
description: clean up or fix the identity problem in nexus core
right now we have a problem of partially applied changes in nexus core and future possible extensions
as we know nexus is now able to handle all of these simple)repository grouprepository shadowrepository as repoository in generic way
this is done by implementation of grouprepository and changes done in routers and registry
moreover nexus is now prepared for any future expansion and addition of new simple repository types
but we have a major mishap here after the change the components that implements repository iface are registered to plexus as components with different roles ie

repository.class for simple reposes grouprepository.class for groups and shadowrepository.class for that said it means that even if we are able to handle them in way programatically plexus will not see anymore them as repository but you will have to specific to why kind of repository you talk about
moreover think about plugin extending if a plugin to introduce a new composite repository for some reasone it will be not able to do it since nexus will not know anything about that new role

summary: nexus indexer future proof api
description: current problems changing fields or contents of fields breaks older clients
for example changing the tokenization adding new fields isn't a problem
lucene binary format can change
currently we use but if the index is opened in the index is irreversibly upgraded
thus we are currently locked in lucene actual problem is that currently the index binary itself is used as the transport mechanism
a proposed solution is to use a different format for transport a format that we can control version and upgrade independently of the lucene format
this data format must have a version element for future purposes

summary: nexus indexer index poms without artifacts and jars without poms
description: in some cases maven repository can have pom.xml with packaging and no corresponding artifact

another possibility is when given pom is used to redirect to the new groupid for example xml version encoding project distributionmanagement relocation distributionmanagement project such redirecting artifacts will create duplicated entries that are create unnecessary noise to the user
given that part of the group usually stays the same it also does not make much sense not to index such poms
to summarize if there is pom.xml with packaging but there is no artifact we should skip it that would also cover skipping this redirecting

summary: test the concurrent task checking
description: the logic used to check if tasks can be run concurrently is now working properly here are the guidelines non repository based tasks a
empty trash b
purge timeline c
remove repo folder only occurs when deleting a repo not exposed as user configurable d

synchronize shadows the tasks listed above will only be allowed to run if there is not already a task of the some type running only one of each task can run at a time but tasks of different types can be run simultaneously repository or group based tasks a
snapshot remover b
publish indexes c
evict unused proxy items d
reindex e
rebuild attributes f
clear cache the tasks listed above will only be allowed to run if there is not already another task running on the same repository

tasks of the same type or different types are allowed to run simultaneously if the following applies both tasks are not assigned to the same repository both tasks are not assigned to the same group both tasks are not assigned to all repositories either task is assigned to a group and that group does not contain a repository the other task is using both tasks are assigned to a group and either group does not contain repositories from the other should a task be found not able to run it will be rescheduled for seconds in the future and the process will be checked again every seconds until the task can run

summary: jsec nexusrealm for jsecurity
description: a realm which obtains mappings from nexussecurityconfiguration
security ui uses mutablenexussecurityconfiguration to modify mappings and specifically not a jsecurity interface
there are two types of permission in nexus application permissions and target repository permission
the application permission is a simple http request uri http verb permission as seen in the servlet spec
the target repository permission is checked using repository target crud operation
the repository target is calculated outside of the security system and is based on a collection of repository regular expressions
additionally a target repository permission can be assigned to a group of targets

when the realm sees a permission for a group of targets it will explode that group into a permission object for each target in the group this vastly simplifies the this realm will use the generic jsecurity wildcardpermission for all permission checks to make integration with other security frameworks opensso easier
